In 2012, I argued that the percent of Google searches that include the word "nigger(s)" was a reasonable measure of racism against African-Americans.  These searches are mostly for disparaging jokes about black people.   The highest area tends to be Appalachia -- West Virginia, Kentucky, western Pennsylvania, eastern Ohio.  They are also high in southern Louisiana and southern Mississippi and upstate New York. (Note that these maps are very different from searches for "nigga(s)" or "n word," both of which are instead searched with great frequency in areas with high African-American populations.)  My paper discussing this research is here (Page on squarespace.com) and was eventually published in the Journal of Public Economics.  ...The Google map tracks remarkably closely with the map of where Obama underperformed Kerry: obama minus kerry map In 2016, my guess is very strong that Democratic performance will pick up in this region....Researchers have recently used Tweets to try to measure racism, and it seems to be somewhat similar to the Google map.  That said, imo, Twitter is not a great source for measuring this.  In contrast to Google, a very small subset of the population uses Twitter. In addition, Tweets are not anonymous; in fact, some people have lost their jobs for making racist Tweets.  For these reasons, there are only a small number of racist Tweets.  The Google dataset instead includes millions of racist searches every year.  One way to think of the difference between Google and Twitter for trying to measure racism: Because Twitter is anonymous, the more socially acceptable word "nigga" is used about one hundred times more than the less acceptable "nigger."  On Google, which is anonymous, for the time period I was looking at, "nigger" was actually more commonly searched than "nigga." ...Another data source is the General Social Survey.  However, this yields small samples.  To get reasonably large samples, you have to aggregate decades of data.  In addition, social desirability bias complicates these results.  The percent of white people who oppose interracial marriage is highest in the South.  But this may be due to social desirability bias.  Whites in Appalachia and the Northeast may be less likely to admit their attitudes....Finally, there is a map of implicit attitudes: Across America, whites are biased and they don’t even know it .  This map also correlates with all the others but is similarly a little more common in the South.  Interestingly, the Google searches are far more predictive of Obama underperformance relative to Kerry than the implicit attitude map is....Overall, then, I think the best evidence is the type of racism that influences black candidates is highest in Appalachia plus southern Louisiana and Mississippi.
